oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Contract in Louisiana. A strong article on this subject recently came out in Hampton's Magazine entitled, "What Eight Million Women Want." Colorado is called "Woman's Paradise," and Louisiana, is contrasted with it. "In Louisiana," says the article, "your disabilities actually begin when you become an engaged girl. [From that] happy moment on, you are under the dominance of a man. Your wedding presents are not yours, but his. Your clothing, your dowry becomes community property as soon as the marriage cere- mony is over and community property in Louisiana is controlled absolutely by lthe husband. During the husband's life- time he is sole guardian of their chil- dren. At his death she may become their guardian, but if she marries again and the law permits her to remarry provided she waits ten months, she re-____________ her children only by formal con- sent of her first husband's family. If they dislike her or disapprove of the second marriage, they may demand the custody of the children. In only ten states are women co-guardians with their husbands of their children." Conditions In Colorado. Miss Jane Addams has declared (after close study of the subject) that the laws in Colorado are superior in reegards to women and children than of any other state. Women in Colorado receive equal pay for equal work, they are guardians of the children and the edu- cation of the children is placed almost entirely in their hands.
